exercise_suggestions.exercise_suggestion: As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 25%
As your exercise is before your meal you will have less active insulin on board and therefore less likely to experience hypoglycaemia
3. No additional carbohydrate should be needed for this duration and intensity of exercise
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l) and at the end of exercise
As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 50%
As your exercise is before your meal you will have less active insulin on board and therefore less likely to experience hypoglycaemia
3. No additional carbohydrate should be needed for this duration and intensity of exercise
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l) and at the end of exercise
As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 75%
As your exercise is before your meal you will have less active insulin on board and therefore less likely to experience hypoglycaemia
3. No additional carbohydrate should be needed for this duration and intensity of exercise
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l) and at the end of exercise
1. Your blood sugar will likely rise with this extremely intense exercise therefore take your usual meal time insulin if your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal
2. No additional carbohydrate should be needed for this duration and intensity of exercise
3. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 5-7mmol/l) and at the end of exercise
As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 50%
As your exercise is before your meal you will have less active insulin on board and therefore you will need less carbohydrate to prevent hypoglycaemia
3. Consume additional carbohydrates as needed based on your blood glucose monitoring (approx 10-15g/hr). Remember the more insulin you have on board the more carbohydrate you will need.
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l), during exercise and at the end of exercise.
As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 75%
As your exercise before your meal you will have less active insulin on board and therefore you will need less carbohydrate to prevent hypoglycaemia
3. Consume additional carbohydrates as needed based on your blood glucose monitoring (approx 10-15g/hr). Remember the more insulin you have on board the more carbohydrate you will need.
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l), during exercise and at the end of exercise.
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate
As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 50%
As your exercise is before your meal you will have less active insulin on board and therefore less likely to experience hypoglycaemia
3. No additional carbohydrate should be needed for this duration and intensity of exercise
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l) and at the end of exercise
As are doing both resistance (e.g weight-lifting) and aerobic (e.g. jogging), do resistance exercise first to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia during and after exercise .

As your exercise is team sports remember a match or competition will likely cause your blood sugars to rise due to nerves / adrenaline, therefore you will need less insulin dose reductions and less carbohydrate than you might need during training
1. Your blood sugar will likely rise with this extremely intense exercise therefore take your usual meal time insulin if your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal
2. You will unlikely need any carbohydrate to prevent hypoglyaemia during exercise but carry some with you
3. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 5-7mmol/l) and at the end of exercise
As your exercise is within 2-3hrs of your meal reduce your mealtime insulin by approx 50%
As your exercise is before your meal you will have less active insulin on board and therefore you will need less carbohydrate to prevent hypoglycaemia
3. Consume additional carbohydrates as needed based on your blood sugar monitoring (e.g. 10-15g/hr). Remember the more insulin you have on board the more carbohydrate you will need.
4. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 7-10mmol/l), during exercise and at the end of exercise.
As you are doing both resistance (e.g weight-lifting) and aerobic (e.g. jogging), do resistance exercise first to reduce the risk of hypoglycaemia during and after exercise .

As your exercise is team sports remember a match or competition will likely cause your blood sugars to rise due to nerves / adrenaline, therefore you will need less insulin dose reductions and less carbohydrate than you might need during training
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate
This exercise intensity is not possible for this duration. Change exercise intensity to moderate
Anaerobic exercise is done at moderate to high intensity. Change to at least 4-6 on the intensity scale
1. As your blood glucose is likely to rise with anaerobic exercise no reduction in mealtime insulin or basal insulin is advised.
2. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 5-7mmol/l) and at the end of exercise.
Anaerobic exercise is done at moderate to high intensity. Change to at least 4-6 on the intensity scale
1. Your blood sugar may rise or remain stable with longer duration anaerobic exercise, therefore no reduction in mealtime insulin or basal insulin is advised initially.
2. Carry some carbohydrate with you as you may need it to prevent hypoglycaemia for longer duration anaerobic workouts
3. Check blood glucose before you start (aim for a starting blood glucose between 5-7mmol/l), during exercise and at the end of exercise.
